message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: move What to Report to standalone file">
Vote requested: Should we move the "What to Report" section (lines 65-95 of the Standby Reader Profile) out of the Profile.md and into a standalone file?

The reasoning: Profile.md will be used as the prompt to generate/spawn the reader agent. If "What to Report" (including the per-essay questions, final prompts, and critical experiential checks) is part of that prompt, the reader will see all those questions BEFORE reading — which could bias their experience (e.g., knowing they'll be asked "What happened to your experience across the three examples?" for Essay 3 could prime them to watch for it).

Moving it to a standalone file means we can give the reader the profile (role, personality, reading instructions) at spawn, and then deliver the reporting questions AFTER they finish reading each piece — keeping the reading experience uncontaminated.

Vote YES to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, or NO to keep it in the profile. Brief reasoning please.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**YES** — move it to a standalone file.

This is exactly the same principle we applied to the Preface: do not pre-deliver what the reader should discover through experience. If the reader knows they will be asked "What happened to your sense of absurdity across the three examples?" before reading Essay 3, they will read Essay 3 with absurdity-tracking already activated. The experiential sequence is designed to produce recognition without priming — the reader should arrive at the cat example without having been told to monitor their own affective response. Delivering the questions afterward preserves the experimental conditions. This is the standby reader as philosophical experiment, and good experiments do not tell the subject what to look for.
input.summary: YES — same principle as Preface spoilers; don't prime the reader

routing.summary: YES — same principle as Preface spoilers; don't prime the reader

The experiential sequence is designed to produce recognition without priming — the reader should arrive at the cat example without having been told to monitor their own affective response.
